caption.p: Summary of Lessons from Past Epidemics and Pandemics

tr.td: The Black Death provided a catalyst for growth of surgical societies throughout medieval Europe by highlighting the inadequacies of existing medical therapies. medical therapy.
The 1918 Spanish Flu pandemic saw the widespread implementation of hospital hygiene and public health measures informed by germ theory that remain foundational to modern surgery.

The HIV/AIDS epidemic raised ethical debates regarding the surgeon’s duty to treat patients at the risk of their own health. The principles of accepting a reasonable level of risk and not discriminating based on seropositivity have prevailed.

The SARS outbreak demonstrated how systemic responses to highly infectious diseases must be flexible. The cancellation of elective surgeries and implementation of enhanced personal protective equipment highlighted the importance of adaptive infection control measures.
The West Africa Ebola epidemic revealed the vulnerability surgeons in resource-poor healthcare systems face during infectious disease epidemics.
The COVID-19 pandemic is once again challenging the surgical community to adapt and advance by demanding flexibility and innovation to address struggles old and new.
